title: New Component Title
body:
There is a further guidance available on this topic, including:

  • Link to new SDC guidance
  • Link to other disclosure courses

 

If you require more bespoke guidance, please contact the Statistical Disclosure Team or Data Quality Team at DQHub@ons.gov.uk.

title: New Component Title
body: A disclosure, or breach of confidentiality, is when data released allows someone to deduce confidential information within the data. Data must be protected before it is released or shared to minimise the risk of disclosure of confidential information about any individual or organisation.

title: Risks
instruction: Select the image to find out more

_captions.text: Harm to those whose information you keep

title: New Component Title
body: Statistical disclosure control (SDC) is a set of techniques that are applied to data in order to identify disclosure risk, and where needed, reduce the risk to an acceptable level.

title: New Component Title
body:
Whenever statistical disclosure is applied there is inevitably some information lost. This is known as a decrease in data utility However, the loss of utility leads to a decrease in the risk of disclosure. When applying SDC, our aim is to maximise the utility of the data, while limiting the risk of disclosure to an acceptable level.

It is almost impossible for data to have zero disclosure risk.

title: Remove the disclosive row
body:
An effective way of protecting the household from being identified is to remove the row with information on 6+ households from the table. The rest of the table is unaffected, so the utility of the table is still high. 

Please note  HTML versions of these tables are also available on this page should you need them.
instruction: Slide the arrow to view the options

_beforeafter.altbefore: The lowest total for either household size or banded income is 11, aside from the household size of 6 or more. There is only one household with more than 6 people on this table.
_beforeafter.alt: The row with the 6+ category has been removed, and the totals have been updated so the one household is no longer included.

title: Remove all values below ten
body:
An alternative would be for all of the values below 10 could be suppressed in the table. This table is now low risk, but this is an ineffective way of protecting the data. A lot of information is lost and so the table isn’t very useful.

Its utility is low.

_beforeafter.alt: All cells containing a number lower than ten have now been replaced with an asterisk. This leaves only 6 out of 36 cells with a figure in them.

title: The balance between risk and utility- example
displayTitle: The balance between risk and utility- example
body:
Calculating the balance between risk and utility is something that we all do regularly in everyday life. 

When you cross a road to reach a shop you will be making this calculation. You could look before crossing, or sprint across the road. How careful should you be?
instruction: Select each option to discover how risky or useful they may be

_items.title: Option one
_items.body:
Risk Analysis

No risk-No chance or getting run over or being badly injured.

Utility analysis

Low- you may not get across the road or the shop may be shut by the time you cross

_graphic.alt: Graph plotting risk (y axis) against utility (x axis).  This option is low against both risk and utility

_pin.alt: Put on suit of armour and crash helmet. Look both ways many times. Do not cross if you see any cars. Do not cross if the road is slippery.

_items.title: Option two
_items.body:
Risk analysis

Low- Unlikely but still a chance of being run over

Utility analysis

Medium- Strategy meets the needs. Shop could still be shut if road is busy.

_graphic.alt: Graph plotting risk (y axis) against utility (x axis). The option is low against risk and medium against utility

_pin.alt: Option two- Wear sensible shoes. Look both ways. Cross if vehicles are not close. Walk at a reasonable pace, keeping looking both ways.

_items.title: Option three
_items.body:
Risk analysis

High- High risk of getting run over.

Utility analysis

High- You'll get to the shop very quickly

_graphic.alt: Graph plotting risk (y axis) against utility (x axis). Both risk and utility are placed highly

_pin.alt: Option three. Don't look both ways. Run.

_items.backBody:
Microdata are data on the characteristics of units in a population, such as individuals, households or establishments. These data can be collected by a census, a sample survey, or from administrative data.

Microdata are also known as record level data, or statistical microdata.

Frequency tables are tables of counts often used to display data collected in surveys or censuses.

Each cell in the table is a frequency or count. An example of a frequency table is the number of males aged over 65 living in a particular geography, such as output area.

Magnitude tables are tables of totals or averages. Magnitude tables are often used to display data from business surveys. Each cell represents a total value, which are the contributors to that cell.

An example of a magnitude table is the total turnover for all businesses in the Petrochemical subsector in the North East region.

_items.title: Statistics of Trade Act (1947)
_items.body:
The key element of the Statistics of Trade Act in relation to statistical disclosure is Section 9 (which refers of the disclosure of information) part 1 which states:

No individual estimates or returns, and no information relating to an individual undertaking, obtained under the foregoing provisions of this Act, shall be disclosed without the previous consent in writing of the person carrying on the undertaking which is the subject of the estimates, returns or information.

_items.title: Statistics and Registration Act (2007)
_items.body:
The Statistics and Registration Service act applies to the Office for National Statistics (ONS) data and defines personal information as information in which the identity of a person or business:

  • is specified in the information
  • can be deduced from the information or
  • can be deduced from the information taken together with any other published information

Any disclosure of personal information is prohibited, except in certain cases, including where the information 'has already been lawfully made available to the public, is made with the consent of the person to who it related, or is made to an approved researcher'.

_items.title: General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) 2018
_items.body:
GDPR mandates protection for personal data from which identities of individuals can be determined from the data itself and other sources held by the data controller.

It refers to special categories of data for which additional care must be taken. These include:

  • ethnic origin
  • political affiliation
  • religion
  • biometrics (for ID purposes)
  • health
  • sexual orientation

_items.title: Data protection Act 2018
_items.body:
The Data Protection Act states that:

' A person must not knowingly or recklessly without the consent of the data controller-

  1. obtain or disclose personal data or the information contained in personal data. or
  2. procure the disclosure to another person of the information contained in personal data'

There are some exceptions under this act for the prevention of crimes, public interest and is the disclosure is legal under other acts.

title: New Component Title
body: Which of these is NOT a realistic scenario for statistical disclosure?

_items.text: A Journalist looking for an interesting news story
A business trying to uncover commercial information about competitors
Someone trying to hack into a database
Someone trying to determine sensitive information about a neighbour

_feedback.title: Feedback
_feedback.correct:
Someone hacking into a database is still a risk to the stored data, but it is not a risk of disclosure control. it is a risk of information security.

The other options are risks of disclosure in published or released data.

_incorrect.notFinal:
Not quite. 

Someone hacking into a database is still a risk to the stored data, but it is not a risk of disclosure control. it is a risk of information security.

The other options are risks of disclosure in published or released data.

title: New Component Title
instruction: Select each text box to find out more about each step

_items.title: Determine user requirements
_items.body:
The first step of the disclosure control process is to determine the needs of those that use the data. 

The needs of the users determine what type of disclosure control would be applicable.

For example, if users are particularly interested in aged of people in a table then the disclosure control method should aim to maintain utility of the age variable wherever possible.

_items.title: Understand the data
_items.body:
The second step of the disclosure control framework is to fully understand what the data represent. 

Knowing how the outputs were constructed and what they mean allows a better understanding of the disclosure risks, and the probability, of disclosures occurring.

_items.title: Is disclosure likely to occur?
_items.body:
The third step of the disclosure control process is to evaluate how likely a disclosure is to occur, and how much of an effect(impact) this would have. 

If the likelihood or impact of disclosure is high, then disclosure control should be applied. 

If the likelihood and impact of disclosure is very low, then disclosure control may not be required.

_items.title: Would disclosure be a breach of law, policy or trust?
_items.body:
The fourth step of the disclosure control process is to determine whether a disclosure would be a breach of law, policy or of public trust. 

Disclosure control must be applied where a disclosure would be a breach of the law, but also in cases where it would undermine the trust of the public. 

A breach of public trust would likely result in fewer volunteers for future surveys, and therefore in less reliable information for future outputs.

_graphic.alt: Would disclosure be a breach of law, policy or trust?

_pin.alt: Would disclosure be a breach of law, policy or trust?

_items.title: Select disclosure control methods and implement
_items.body:
Once disclosure has been determined to be an issue, appropriate statistical disclosure control (SDC) methods should be employed to reduce the risk of the data. 

Other e-learning module sin this series will cover some of the methods that can be used for the appropriate data formats.

_graphic.alt: Select disclosure control methods and implement

_pin.alt: Select disclosure control methods and implement

_items.title: Publish the data
_items.body: The final stage of the process is the publication of the data.

title: Types of intruder
body: Intruders, also known as attackers, are those who try to determine confidential information about a respondent from a dataset.

_items.title: Are intruders always malicious?
_items.body:
Some intruders are malicious, but not all. For example, a journalist may be looking to write a public interest story, and find information about an organisation in a dataset.

Even if this is not done with malicious intent, this is still an instance of statistical disclosure.

_items.title: Are intruders always deliberate?
_items.body:
Not every intruder acts deliberately.

Some intruders might deliberately attempt to determine confidential information about a respondent from a dataset.

Other intruders may inadvertently determine this information. Both of these scenarios should be taken seriously, and data should be protected from disclosure as much as possible.

_items.title: Are intruders always strangers?
_items.body:
An intruder can be an acquaintance using information gained by knowing the respondent to uncover confidential information in your data. For example, someone’s job role and grade could be used to find out their salary if this information is available.

An intruder could also be a stranger using information available in the public domain to discover more about a respondent. For example, information found in newspaper articles could be used to identify a respondent in a dataset.

_items.title: Identity theft
_items.body: Intruders may want to find personal information in order to commit identity theft.

_graphic.alt: Person sits at computer with several screens open

_items.title: Enhance private databases
_items.body: Private companies may be looking to add more information to their own databases than currently held.

_graphic.alt: Group of people sit at table working on laptops

_items.title: Gain against competitors
_items.body: Companies may be looking for confidential information that can give them a commercial advantage over their competitors.

_graphic.alt: Bank notes are spread across a surface

_items.title: Public interest
_items.body: Journalists may want information for a public interest story.

_graphic.alt: Group of people sit and take notes

_items.title: To find out sensitive information
_items.body: People may be looking for information about others such as their income of health.

_graphic.alt: Doctor in white lab coat holds a stethoscope

_items.title: Discreditation
_items.body: Some intruders may be looking to discredit the Government or the Analysis function.

_graphic.alt: Houses of parliament in the background, some boats are sailing on the river in the foreground

title: New Component Title
body: Which action should be completed before assessing whether there is a risk of disclosure?

_items.text: Asses which intruders are interested in the data

_feedback.title: Feedback
_feedback.correct: Correct, you must make sure that you understand the data you are working with before you make any assessment of disclosure risk.

_incorrect.final: Incorrect, you must make sure that you understand the data you are working with before you make any assessment of disclosure risk.

title: New Component Title
body: Why is it important to apply disclosure control to protect confidential data?

_items.text: To make sure that key researchers have priveledged access
To maintain trust so that people will consent to share information
To maximise the utility of the data

_feedback.title: Feedback
_feedback.correct:
Statistical disclosure control is important because it minimises disclosure of private information. This is a legal requirement according to several UK laws.

Additionally, it is important to maintain the trust of the public to ensure that they consent to share information.

Disclosure control may not maximise the utility of the data - in order to keep information private there may have to be a loss of some utility.

Disclosure control is not intended to be a process which designates which researchers have access to datasets.

_incorrect.final:
Statistical disclosure control is important because it minimises disclosure of private information. This is a legal requirement according to several UK laws.

Additionally, it is important to maintain the trust of the public to ensure that they consent to share information.

Disclosure control may not maximise the utility of the data - in order to keep information private there may have to be a loss of some utility.

Disclosure control is not intended to be a process which designates which researchers have access to datasets.
_incorrect.notFinal:
Statistical disclosure control is important because it minimises disclosure of private information. This is a legal requirement according to several UK laws.

Additionally, it is important to maintain the trust of the public to ensure that they consent to share information.

Disclosure control may not maximise the utility of the data - in order to keep information private there may have to be a loss of some utility.

Disclosure control is not intended to be a process which designates which researchers have access to datasets.

title: Freedom of Information Act
body: Another law to be aware of is the Freedom of Information Act (FOI) 2000 which gives rights of public access to information held by public authorities.

title: New Component Title
body:
This is a full (non-sampled) table for a small area of income bands and household size. The problem is that the table reveals the banded income of the largest household. If you know the household with at least 6 people in it, you can work out that they have an annual income between 0 and 9999 pounds. 

 

Annual household income

Household size 0 to 9,999 10,000 to 19,999 20,000 to 39,999 40,000 to 59,999 60,000 to 79,999 80,000 to 79,999 Total
1 3 7 15 4 0 0 29
2 2 2 15 16 8 4 47
3 1 4 9 18 5 5 42
4 4 8 8 10 10 2 42
5 1 0 2 4 3 1 11
6+ 1 0 0 0 0 0 1
Total 12 21 49 52 26 12 172
